Booked in for lunch after visiting the National Stud. Very welcoming and unhurried. Beef was pink in the middle (just as I like it). Sausage & mash went down well with the younger member of the group. Adnams Ghost Ship on draught served just right. Will return when next in the area.
Interesting food, large portions well cooked and not too expensive. Relaxed atmosphere with great service would be happy to return.

We popped in as we were passing lunchtime on a thursday. It was not very busy in the bar area. We ordered Liver and bacon on mash dish and a fish pie dish. Although the wait was 40 minutes the food was excellent, tasty, hot and enough so that we could not fit in a dessert. The bar staff were very pleasant and welcoming. Only downside was children in the bar but then that's us being past that stage :-) .

we booked a meal on a Sat night,quite busy but no issues.My wife had the old haloumi salad typical for vegys and i had a starter mushrooms on toast in sauce.this was gorgeous,followed by a big gammon and all trimmings,lovely.To end we shared sticky toffee pudding.Complete meal was lovely and well the prices we paid.We sat in restaurant side ,a little better than bar side but both sides typical country pub.Staff were very friendly,would recommend if near by.

Wanting to have an evening outside the hotel we were staying at this was an excellent find and the food was delightful. Bar staff were very helpful and, although not busy, did not feel that we were being pushed out whilst finishing off our drinks

Visited for lunch having been to nearby Anglesey Abbey. The menu is not huge but should have something to please anyone, with a mixture of pub classics and more unusual meals. My husband had fish and chips and I had the halloumi salad. Both were absolutely delicious. The chef was kind enough to make a plate of sausage and vegetables for our picky toddler even though this is not really on the menu. Service was friendly and helpful although not fast when it started to get busy. Would highly recommend!

Four of us booked a table for dinner after being recommended by a friend. Matt the landlord is a relaxed but very welcoming host. The range of beers was excellent and Matt knowledge and recommendations were first class. Two of our party had chicken and mushroom in a cream sauce and really enjoyed it. One had forest mushrooms on toast and asked for it without cream, the chef duly obliged and my friend really enjoyed the flavours and variety of mushrooms served. I had a seasonal dish off the menu which was a lamb burger with a hint of chilli and mint sauce. Everything was so fresh and tasty and the pub really relaxed and friendly. I would really recommend taking time to find this lovely pub.

Looking for a quick lunch meal after a nice walk and before an afternoon event. Saw the signs and pulled in. At first look we were a bit unsure as externally it looks like a small local, geared towards local trade. But, we needn't have worried. The greeting was warm and the restaurant area, whilst plain, was clean. The drinks took a wee while but that was a minor point, only one staff on. The menu was varied, but we not wanted a light lunch so went for hot sandwiches. They were swift in arrival and delicious, both bacon & brie and sausage and onion were served in soft toasted ciabatta and the chips were well cooked. A nice greeting, and overall a hidden gem.

My husband and I had a fantastic meal at the White Swan last Sunday evening. He had the fillet steak and I had fish and both were delicious - as were our chosen desserts of chocolate terrine and crumble. We would definitely recommend the White Swan for their food.

So why not give a score of five stars? It was because our first impressions were disappointing as it felt like we were sitting in the bar rather than a restaurant. I had expected a properly laid table (not just a cheap paper napkin with a knife and fork placed on top of it) a wine list (even if it isn't finalised) and smartly presented staff (not wearing T-shirt, jeans, leggings and casual jumper).

Would we return? Yes! The food was delicious, the staff were friendly, the prices were reasonable so don't be put off by first impressions!

What lovely, quality food! The best burger I have eaten in decades! I would go back anyday! The rest of the crowd ate fish and chips and it was great quality too!
Friendly staff. Not a luxurious ambience but so calm and friendly- you feel very comfortable!

I would highly recommend it for people who like to eat out and leave with full gratification!

We dined in this pub/restaurant one evening in April. The restaurant was deathly quiet so we opted to eat in the nice-looking bar of the pub. The food was average as was the service. Very strangely, there was no wine list!

Four of us booked a table for Sunday lunch. I must say the food was excellent. Two of us had lamb, one had beef and the other was pork. By the time I had finished I never had any room for a sweet. Two of our party had the sticky toffee pudding to share. I wish I had saved enough room for one because it was delicious.
Will definitely go back and it is very advisable to book.

Just called in to the White Swan for lunch and what a treat, excellent food and a good selection of beers and wines (as you would expect from a pub). If there is a down side to this pub it is that the interior could do with up dating. By far their biggest asset though is the wonderful staff.

We were staying in The Quy Mill hotel and wanted a bit of "pub grub"
Managed to get the last table so we knew it would be a bit busy.
Food was lovely, I had the pork and cider pie and my wife had the gammon, both were great. The panna cotta for desert was to die for, I ordered a portion only for myself as my wife was too full from the main course, however she got a second spoon and helped me finish it!!! Food was worth every penny but the service was a little slow. One of the 2 female bar/service staff didn't seem to do much leaving the other to run around servicing everyone so things did drag a bit. We would go back but probably on a quieter night
Really nice food, good service for 15 of us well looked after by staff, great selection of food, recommend to friends . Will visit again!!
Good well cooked food. Service good very friendly staff. Lunch menu not as interesting as a few months ago

I brought my parents here for lunch; we had a lovely meal, but I'm glad we weren't in a hurry! Our table was reserved for 12:30 and we didn't order starters; our main courses didn't arrive until gone 13:20. I think they were unexpectedly busy, but still.

That said, the food was really good - my steak was done just as I like it, and the mushroom sauce with it was really tasty. My Mum really enjoyed the duck leg, and Dad really enjoyed his gnocchi. They had 4 different real ales on (and the one I had was well kept). Food was very reasonably priced, too, especially given the quality which was really good.

Everyone agreed it'd been a really nice meal, we'd just liked to have not waited quite so much!

Visited today with my sister and nephew on way back from Anglesey Abbey, we went in not expecting to get a table, but thought we would just have a drink.
The pub and restaurant was busy, but we were acknowledged on arrival by a friendly smile from the landlord. He asked if we had a table reservation and when I said we didn't, he said that hopefully in 20 mins he might be able to help.
When I saw the fine selection of real ales I was very pleased to wait.
The meal was simply just as good a Sunday Roast as you could possibly wish for.
Excellently portion size, the lamb was generous and cooked to perfection.
We all enjoyed ourselves very much and will definitely return.
I understand the inn is under new management since November 2015, I wish them every success.

Thoroughly enjoyed our visit here in January. The place was cosy, friendly and well run. We had a lovely meal that was made with really fresh ingredients, it was well cooked and nicely presented.
The bar was stocked with interesting things from craft ales to aged single malt whiskeys. I would really recommend this place to anyone looking for a cosy, relaxed and welcoming establishment.

Lunch here with our walking group. Cosy retreat from the cold January wind of the Fens. Warm welcome in charming surroundings. Service helpful, cheery, informal, even a bit funky. Light lunches round the table: thrice cooked chips; leek and potato soup; jacket potatoes with toppings; various combinations of tasty things in ciabatta, e.g. sausage, goatâ€™s cheese & roasted vegetables. All voted very good. Selection of interesting ales. Definitely one to go back to and try the dinner menu.

Note: very handy for visitors to excellent nearby Anglesey Abbey; and good out of town option if you are visiting Cambridge and want to escape clone food.

PS Donâ€™t miss the extraordinary sign outside â€“ look hard and the swan will reveal itself.

We ventured to Anglesey Abbey and unfortunately could not get into the grounds as we had our dogs with us; so settled for a nice walk along the river to the nearby village and found the White Swan. We asked about the dogs coming in - not a problem!
We settled with our two children (7&10) in the bar area, which is a proper pub. The restaurant side is lovely too but for us today as we were kitted up for walking.

I do like to be able to sit in a pub without the expectation that you are going to eat.

Well, we chose to eat, and the menu was lovely. My wife had the Nut Roast and I and the children opted for Sausage & Mash. Roasts & Fish options we're available, and is was also nice to see that smaller portions were available throughout.
Everything was great - Food, Quantity, Service, Beer, Atmosphere and Price.

We will return without the dogs to the Abbey and book ahead for another visit this pub 10/10

We were just passing through from a visit to Anglesey Abbey and fancied a Sunday lunch before travelling home. To be fair it didn't look much on the inside but it was deceptive. The bar was on the right hand side and the eating area/rooms were in the extended building to the left - so a bit of a tardis really. We ordered 2 Sunday lunches at Â£12 each but after 40 minutes the Manageress came over to advised that our ticket had not been put through and she'd realised we were sitting here not eating. She apologised profusely, took our order again and we waited 5 mins for it to arrive. The Sunday lunches were second to none.. full large plates of really good food. Leg of lamb meat, cooked nicely and a larger amount - roast beef both with large crispy roasted potatoes, a hugely risen Yorkshire pudding and ample baked vegetables. The food was delicious, however this is not the end... sorry no dessert as there really wasn't room after that LARGE Sunday roast and I really wanted the chocolate brownie. No the best bit was that after the apology our waitress brought over the dinners and advised us that they were on the house. We were in total shock. Yes a error had been made, but we were not expecting to get our food for free. The Manageress was straight forward, no bumbling, just plain excellent service for an error that was made right (obviously we didn't no pay for both, we offered to pay for one of them at least) Although we were juts passers-by and not regulars, we were treated with the utmost of respect and I have to say that I've only ever once before received UNCONDITIONAL customer service like this before!

100% on that and for the food. I couldn't recommend you any more than this.. I shall be back for the brownie when I am next at Anglesey Abbey or in the area.

THANK YOU.

Oh my goodness, what a find, Had searched for a veggie Sunday roast in Cambridge, and this pub came up. (Thank goodness) Very well cooked roast potatoes, delicious home made nut roast. My partner had roast lamb which he said was delicious too. Pudding was sticky toffee pudding with butter scotch sauce, Again it tasted amazing. The pub was dated, and slightly chilly, We were first in the room but it soon warmed up as it filled up! But this did not matter to us in the least. Staff friendly and very helpful, Thank you.

We had an early evening dinner for the first time at The White Swan a week ago and it was excellent in every way. There is a new owner who seems to be working really hard to refurbish the decor and judging by what he's done so far it's going to be a real treasure of a place. The menu has just the right amount of choices and we were delighted with the freshness of produce, the chef is a gem and it was such good value for the quality. It has a really friendly atmosphere, great wine and beer choices. The only negative thing I would say is that I don't live round the corner. Highly recommended and we look forward to visiting again.

Visited this pub after seeing seeing some if the fab reviews.

The food was OK, but the service was shocking.

20 minutes from when the first meal arrived to the last, and then some items weren't correct.

Some of our friends had finished their food, before others even got theirs!

The waitress was getting confused with which steak was which, luckily we all ended up with he correct meals in the end.

Drink prices were horrendous. Â£9.60 for two large wines

The food itself was OK, plates were hot (maybe they could tell you this before handing them to you).

Side orders were a joke, as they didn't appear until the end of the meal.

We asked for sauces but they didn't arrive until the end, the French mustard isn't really French mustard, more of a mayo combination that was disgusting.

Management blamed staffing issues, but two of them sat talking behind the bar whilst the poor waitress had to deal with everything.

All staff were grumpy, and management came across as couldn't give two tosses.

Won't be going there again, couldn't wait to get out.

Don't go if you are a large group or if your in a hurry!

Arrived for lunch having read reviews. Were seated in dining area - modern ish little atmosphere by just before 12:30. Waited for drinks. Waited maybe 20 minutes further and went to ask if we could perhaps order some food. Apologies proffered and assurance food would be with us within 30 minutes. Alarm bells should have gone off then.
Asked for Internet code. The sole waitress/bar person in charge did not know it. The landlord did not turn up till 1:00. Customers continued to be admitted and seated although the prospect of any hot food was rapidly receding.
By 1:30 no sign of food and asked again. 1:45 wrong order arrived. By then hungry cold fed up we left. Landlord blamed staff shortage but really we should have been told at the start that food would be very late and given the chance to go somewhere else. That would have been the honest option.Had the landlord actually been present it might have happened.

Dined with another couple and we all agreed it was a very pleasant pub with well cooked food. The beer selection was quite good for a small village pub and the atmosphere was fine, even though the dining side wasn't full to capacity. A small car park is behind the pub.

My only negative comment would be the menu could have just a few more dishes to choose from. Food was delicious though and the value was unbelievable.

The staff were very very helpful and pleasant (thank you very much, if you read this)

Visited the White Swan on the off chance whilst waiting to check in to local hotel.
Do not be put off by the place being small and not having up to date decor. The food was delicious.
My husband had lamb pie and I had the fish finger sandwhich, both were freshly homemade and of excellent quality at a very reasonable price
Would highly recommend to anyone wanting a good pub atmosphere and great food, a great find and if I was in the area again I would definitely return.

After giving up on driving into Cambridge due to traffic, took a detour to Stow cum Quy for a quick lunch. Based on the reviews in TA, headed for the The White Swan which is a typical British pub in a small town. Theres limited parking behind the pub which is reached via a narrow lane just past the entrance to the pub. The restaurant section looked quite nice but I chose the bar area which had limited tables and was much more casual.

Food was good and hearty but nothing really special. Service was a bit slow but probably due to the crowd inside. Nice range of local ales and spirits. All in all a very nice place to get some traditional Pub Grub after a day out in Cambridge.

There was a great range of real ales to choose from! Oakham Ales in particular caught my husband's eye, and he decided to sample the "famous" ribs to accompany his pint. The ribs deserve their reputation, fall-off-the-bone tender and absolutely delicious. That said, my goats cheese foccacia was also extremely tasty so I was happy with my choice. Lovely welcoming atmosphere and staff, I would recommend this as a pub well worth visiting.

Friends & I called in for lunch after a walk around the Anglesey Abbey area.
We were not disappointed from the welcome by the Landlady to the food which was served and on top of that a good pint from local breweries is served, We were made very welcome both by the log fire (which on this day was not needed) to the friendliness of the place - Thank you, we will be back again.

I have eaten at this English country pub, two to three times every week for the past 18 months and I have tried virtually everything on the various standard menus (weekly lunch / weekly dinner Monday / Sunday Lunch / Sunday Dinner) and most of the specials mains / deserts that regularly change. The building is divided into a restaurant and a bar. I prefer to eat in the bar because I enjoy the atmosphere and friendly banter. If we are with my elderly Father in law he prefers the quieter setting of the restaurant. The bar has 4 real ale pumps, Tribute and Ghost Ship are regular beers, there is normally an Oakham ale and a guest from a local brewery. Other Draught drinks include Guinness, Fosters, Carlsberg, krombacher and Aspall cider. The pub does not have a soda fountain so drinks are either bottled or cans. There is a good range of spirits both standard brands and premium brands. I am not a wine drinker but my Father in Law enjoys the Chilean Merlot from the pubs wine list.
Particular favorites from the daily lunch menu are the fish finger (chefs own not Birdseye!) sandwich and the burger (with added cheese / bacon /bbq sauce).
I would recommend any of the Sunday roasts, not the cheapest pub roast you will find but expertly prepared from fresh quality ingredients.
From the daily dinner menu starters, my personal favorite is the Ham hock terrine with chefs own piccalilli but the regularly changing home made soups are always excellent (and the soups are definitely prepared from fresh ingredients in the pubs own kitchen which surely is the definition of home made?) I particularly enjoyed the thick Ham and pea soup severed with a hunk of fresh soft white bread that I had yesterday evening.
From the weekly dinner menu, I would recommend the BBQ ribs, lots of meat that just falls off the bone excellent value, the fillet steak which is very reasonably priced and always cooked perfectly as ordered. My wife particularly likes the sausages and mash and the meat pies which again change regularly.
For desert, the chocolate brownie is delicious and a firm favorite with us but the sticky toffee pudding is slightly better value and equally as filling on a cold winters evening. If you are looking for a lighter desert I would recommend the mango sorbet which has almost an ice cream texture. Do not to forget to check / ask if there are any special deserts, sometimes they are not on any of the menus, this weeks Baked Vanilla Cheesecake with apple compote is so good I had a piece Tuesday and Wednesday evening and if there is fresh batch Saturday I will probably have it again!! The staff are always efficient and very friendly and make everybody feel welcome. This a real pub, run by real people rather than manged to a manual provided by a corporate brewery, serving real ales and freshly prepared quality food.

Tried out this nice village pub for lunch today. Great wooden stove. Super beer.
A simple soup, supposedly home made, was Â£5.50. Quality was 4 out of 10. Same for the bread. Had much better last week in a Norfolk village pub for Â£4.95. Pity that something simple cannot shine.

We rang The White Swan on the off chance that they could fit us in for Sunday lunch and a very friendly lady said they could. We arrived 5 minutes later to find a table had been laid for us. They were extremely busy, but we were made welcome. We all had the Sunday roast (three beef, one pork) and they were happy to make gluten free gravy for one of our party. The food was delicious; hot, good sized portions and very nicely presented. We did have to wait rather a long time for pudding, but the place was packed and very busy. We would certainly recommend The White Swan and shall return when we are next visiting the Cambridge area.
We were a party of seven, tight for time, on a Monday lunchtime. We were welcomed warmly and served appropriately quickly with lovely freshly cooked food. Our first time here but we will be back.

Lovely little pub with a great selection of seriously high standard food. Really imaginative menu with excellent veggie options. Great service and very good beer. Next time, we'll make sure we leave room for the desserts - which looked just as great as everything else.

I booked this pub/restaurant for a Sunday lunch for 8 (including teens and children) and we really enjoyed it. The food was delicious, we had free range pork, roast beef and the gammon special in our group and everyone was very impressed. Our waiter and waitress were very attentive and polite and made sure we had everything we needed. We would definitely go again.

Visiting my sister and partner so always go to their local pub. This time we visited for Sunday lunch. Delicious food and plenty of crispy roast potatoes, vegetables and gravy. All four of us ate something different and we were all very pleased with the food. Superb roast beef, pork and lamb plus the vegetarian. Scrumptious. You could not fault it.

If you want lovely food, great wines and real ale this is the pub for you.

The ribs in particular are a showstopper amongst the wonderful choice of food. Me and my boyfriend don't think we've ever had ribs so tender!

All in all a great Friday evening meal to finish a stressful week. Will definitely go back again and try some more of the menu! I think steak could be next!

Visited here recently with my wife and was really impressed with the warm friendly welcome and the outstanding food both quality and portion size. I am a big eater and I had the smoked chicken salad as a starter and my wife has the ham hock terrine both or which were absolutely fabulous. I followed with a ribeye steak, cooked medium rare with mushroom sauce and my wife had the whole plaice which was on as a special. We also had a bottle of the New Zealand Sav which was absolutely beautiful. I would definitely recommend this place. I have driven by it lots of times but nexer stopped before more's the pity.
I concur with the majority of the reviews on this site that this place is a real hidden gem, not sure why anyone would say anything else. I regularly eat in Michelin starred restaurants, rarely comment on public web sites but I thought The White Swan was really nice, its true it is not a Michelin star place but then again I think it just sets out to be a great village pub with lovely food. Keep up the good work
and thank you
Small restaurant. Had been recommended to us by a friend. Unfortunately it was not as good as we had expected. The food was a little bland and the portion sizes were small for the money.

Stopped here on the way to Newmarket races
Lovely food , very welcoming and excellent service
Fantastic home cooked food
Will call again

We visited this lovely pub with a family group.
Super atmosphere,super staff, wonderful food.
This is a great place to eat informally or more formally in the restaurant. A great local pub where you are sure of a warm welcome.
Well worth a visit.

We are always on the lookout for a pub with a welcoming landlord/lady, with less of the gastro and more of the honest and reasonable priced food, and I'm pleased to say that the recommendations on TripAdvisor of the White Swan did not disappoint. We met friends for a lunch there on a Saturday and all thoroughly enjoyed the food. The Landlady was great and the local at the bar recommending the Adnams was spot on. The White Swan do keep a lovely drop of ale. We will definitely be returning.

Probably one of the best places for Sunday lunch in Cambridge.
Have eaten here loads of times and am never disappointed, the Sunday sharing platter is amazing, always very tasty and plenty of it.
My son and his girlfriend had hangovers and didn't come with us so we asked if they could do take out, yes they did, let us a thermal box to transport it, my son was amazed there was enough food for 4 people.
I have since taken a friend and her daughter for lunch, again the food was fantastic, you also feel like your custom counts, the staff go out of their way to make sure everyone is happy.

I've visited this place now many times. I stay at a nearby hotel next to the A14 that has an excellent reputation for its food and is a quality hotel but the White Swan is a fine little pub and well worth walking from the nearby hotel. The welcome is always warm. It's a pub with a very traditional feel but what sets it apart is the quality of the food. Wholesome, hearty and very well prepared it is brought along to your table by attentive and willing staff who cannot do enough for you. This small and welcoming establishment is off the beaten track and should not be missed. Give it a go, it has never disappointed me and I'm sure it won't dissapoint you.

This is not a huge pub but the food & service is fabulous. We had lunch, there were 30 or so of us in the group & we pre ordered earlier in the morning.
I have no idea how a kitchen copes with a party but we chose from a comprehensive menu & delivery was fast. Quality was good & all thought it was great value.
This is the second time in a month we have used the White Swan & food & service was terrific both times.

Food, drink and service are all wonderful at this venue. What a treat to find it, despite living 15 miles away for so long I had never heard of this pub, yet will definitely return. Staff couldn't do enough for you and the food is presented well and is very tasty. Would recommend for families too as the next table had a child under 5 (who told the waitress his meal was "delicious!") and the staff were very accommodating.

We were on our way from Cheshire to Ipswich and turned off the A14 before Newmarket to gong somewhere to eat.
We drove around a bit and having found a nice looking Italian which was fully booked and then walked in and quickly out of a nearby local pub, we were getting a bit desperate.
Luckily we saw a sign for the Swan and thought we would stop, grab a drink and something to eat. The pub is located in a small village and has that local pub look. There is a car park at the side. If you park here then the door takes you in to the bar, which was full of locals. The decor is typical local but don't be put off.
This is a family owned pub and the welcome was friendly and efficient. The menu is varied and there was a specials menus as well.
We ordered the fish pie which was absolutely delicious and packed with fish. The couple on the next table ordered steaks and were highly complimentary about the quality of the food.
There is also a good range of beers - real ale which always helps.
We got chatting to the landlord who was very welcoming and friendly.
If you are I the area give this pub a try. Highly recommend.

This little pub doesn't look much from the outside but please don't let that put you off.
A warm welcome awaits you inside and no snooty looks from the locals who obviously use the pub a lot, a nice change.
We chose to eat in the bar and the food was fabulous, I've eaten in expensive places that weren't a patch on this !
If you in the area and fancy proper food without the price tag and much more flavour give this place a try.
I usually eat the veggie option and my butternut Wellington served on a onion and rosemary purÃ©e was so tasty and my desert a gooey fudge brownie as delicious , I am usually a bit tight with my reviews but honestly I really loved this little gem of a place.
A beautiful little village pub with a good selection of ales and a sensible, unpretentious menu. A little pricey perhaps, but you get what you pay for.

So more than 30 of us ordered lunch prior to a 3 hour walk arriving back about 12.30 am.
Service was friendly and efficient. Food was good. I had the meat pie which had slightly rubbery pastry. Those who had various sandwiches were delighted.
It is really difficult to judge food with such a large party but all in all they did a good job. It is looking a bit tired but the service is great.

We arrived for lunch after visiting a National Trust House and thought maybe this was a mistake as the decor outside and in was a little tired. Spirits were lifted when I spotted two of my favourite draught beers. The staff were delightful and although the tables could have perhaps done with a scrub the food was first rate. Sunday roast for three of us with a nut roast for the fourth with an onion and red wine gravy that was perfect with this dish. A real country pub with good food and real ales.

Have visited 'The White Swan' on a number of occasions mainly for a drink and a handful of times to eat and I am unable to fault the place. Very attentive staff, food always yummy and presented to a very high standard an a price I like. Lovely 'country pub' atmosphere which I feel caters exceptionally well for locals and in fact for all visitors. This is certainly the best pub in Stow Cum Quy and in fact the best pub around! I will be back!!

this place does what it says on the tin! the food is fantastic for the price you pay! its very pub grub but to a standard of satisfactory above the rest. the locals are very friendly and the owners are very welcoming! this place should be more popular than the rest of the competition in the village! this is a proper pub with a mixed clientele! a place that everywhere used to be!

We visited this country pub on a weekday lunchtime. The staff were very friendly and there was a more than adequate menu selection, for vegetarians as well. The food was excellent, as was the service. There was a good food of the day section
I will not hesitate to visit again when in the area.
I had read about the parking facilities but I would say that this is adequate and there is on street parking.

I have recently moved to the area and I am most pleased to say that this is my local. We bring all of our visitors to The White Swan for a really authentic pub atmosphere, surprisingly excellent food and a warm welcome from the owners and patrons.

A fantastic pub. The experience that my work colleague and I had at this pub was great. It is what you would expect of a traditional country pub. A great selection of CAMRA ales and beers just a shame I was on a business lunch! The lunch menu had a great selection and considering that the pub was busy I was promptly served and the food was exactly as I had asked for it (Crispy Bacon-Perfik!) Really made me wish I lived closer so I could visit more often. I will visit again when in the area and recommend it to all my friends that go that way. Thanks again to the two young ladies behind the bar that served well. (I believe one was the manageress â€“ great job).

Eight of us met at the White Swan for a business meeting, previous booked. The meeting space was set out our for us and upon arrival, we were welcomed with coffee. We then chose of lunch so that it would be ready for us. We had our meeting and on the stroke of 1 o'clock as arranged, lunch was ready and served. Had to get a quick beer in first and there was a good selection from different breweries. The meal looked attractive, it was hot and tasted delicious. We thanked our hosts and booked for the next meeting.

What a great Pub,lovely food ( though like most of the places on my travels, don't take AMEX).But leaving my expense policy out of this ,it was lovely food, at a reasonable price with a good choice.But more important to me, what a lovely pub, a good range of real ales,tasters if you want,really friendly staff and customers (the landlord drove me back to my hotel ,the first time I called in).Its a real good change, if your stopping in the hotel like me, and I would recommend The White Swan to anyone who asked, I will make sure I get back there, the next time I work in the Cambridge area.Dave

We visited this establishment purely by chance on the way to Anglesea Abbey without any reservation. We were made very welcome and the range of food and drinks available were explained efficiently and with enthusiasm, especially the local real ales which is my favourite. The lovely landlady quickly offered my self and my friend tasters before we made our selection. Our wives enjoyed the wine they chose as well. All of our 4 meals were served with an appropriate wait and were superb. They all were very well cooked and presented and great value for money. We thanked the landlord and Lady and complimented them on the food and how well the beer was cared for.( I brew beer and recognise when the equipment is kept well)
We will certainly return.

We had been waiting for good weather to visit Anglesey Abbey but after looking on the NT website did not feel that the restaurant/canteen would be suitable so looked for a pub nearby.

We found The White Swan through TA and arrived just before opening time on a beautifully sunny day.
I had telephoned the day before to ensure that I could get my wife in with her wheelchair and was told it would be fine and they had a ramp if required.
On arrival we were welcomed by the landlord and his wife and seated in the bar by a sunny window.
We had intended to eat in the restaurant section but decided on the bar as it was very pleasant and more convenient and in the event we did not need the wheelchair as my wife was able to walk the few steps from the sideway into the bar.
From then on our whole experience was excellent, the food was very good, I had a homemade pork and cider pie with chips and my wife the fish pie.
Both were accompanied with side orders of vegetables which were cooked to perfection.
Being a lover of real ale I had a choice of four, local and guest beers.
The one I had was kept well.
For sweet, my wife had apple and rhubarb crumble (plenty of fruit) and I had chocolate brownie with ice cream.

The staff were all very friendly and we will not hesitate to visit again if we are in the area.

I would only make one observation, and that would be to charge more for the main courses, I felt that Â£9.50 for each of the main courses was very good value whereas the charge of Â£6.50 for the sweets felt too much for what we got.
The bill would have been the same reasonable amount of course but psychologically more satisfying if the mains were Â£10.50 and sweets Â£5.50 :)
The food is great, what a little gem to have hidden away in Cambridgeshire! Staff are great, it's a cozy little pub with some fab wines too.

We visited this pub as we were staying at the Best Western just 2 minutes down the road. From the outside we could only see the bar and were debating going in as we weren't sure it would offer the sort of food we were looking for but we couldn't have been more wrong. The bar area is cosy but there is a restaurant at the back that is very smart and comfortable. The food was excellent and it was obvious that everything was made from scratch from the bread to the home-made pies (which were delicious!). The service was friendly and welcoming and the meal was excellent value considering the high quality - we will definitely go back if near the area again.
Cozy pub with wood burner fire roaring away. Handy for Angelsea Abbey National Trust. Had homemade hearty soup and fresh hunk of bread Which was very tasty. Good friendly service.We will be back!

We visited after seeing the queue at the cafe at Anglesey Abbey. We had a a very nice soup they made themselves with some nice bread and a drink. The staff are very friendly and the service was excelleny.

Visited this pub/restaurant after taking friends from Bristol to see the snow drops at Anglesey Abbey. Great idea of the boss to have an advertising sign as you drive out of the Abbey and as you go through the village on your way to the A14.
Welcome was great from staff who directed us into the restaurant where we could have the bar snack menu if we chose. Got a 'beer' very quickly with a variety of true beers on offer. Ordered bar food from a very pleasant waitress. There was a specials menu available too. Even though the place was very busy, especially for a Friday lunchtime, food came very quickly and was superb. Hot, appetizing and cooked to perfection and very reasonable. Â£37 (plus tip) for 4 meals and 4 drinks. Well worth a visit. The patio area was not yet geared up for summer, only smokers. No doubt that will happen within the next few weeks.

We are regular visitors to the Swan,on this occasion we were an unusual Valentines group as there was 6 of us!
The White Swan never disappoints,the friendly welcome,lovely warm welcoming bar and fantastic food. Super choice and great vegetarian options.
Nothing is too much trouble. A great place to meet old friends and make new ones.
Well done the White Swan team.

We did some research before making a table reservation at The White Swan as we are retired and have all the time in the world.
The restaurant is attached on one side of the pub and kept separate from the bar area on the other side.
Nice cosy atmosphere in a small restaurant with comfortable seating.
The menu was ample enough for us to choose a dish and I opted for Fish and Chips as I had had steak the previous evening.My wife chose the fish pie which she enjoyed.For dessert we both chose the sticky toffee pudding which we both enjoyed.
We both enjoyed the evening and thought that the food was of a high standard and the two young ladies serving were friendly and professional.

weeks ago for a family meal for three for Sunday lunch. We arrived and to start with there is simply no parking anywhere. Which sometimes happens in country pubs, if you don't mind parking in a tight country road it's fine.
Well, apparently they had over booked! We were asked if we wanted to eat in the bar, a small bar full of people, tiny tables, busy room with lots of people wandering around, it's a bar after all, not what we had booked
A small pub with big food flavours, really good quality dishes from ribs to pies and many others, these are well thought out dishes, we've been numerous times and have never been disappointed yet.
Very tasty home cooked pub food washed down with good beer. The staff were wonderfully friendly. The decor needs updating though. Great place for a no fuss lunch.

We were going to head into the city but thought better of it, my wife suggested we try here and we were suitably impressed. The menu was very broad and all dishes we chose were very well prepared and freshly cooked. My only comment is the place is somewhat basic, paper napkins, quite sparsely furnished and lacks the finishing touches to make it a serious contender as a 'real' eatery!! With a bit more effort on the presentation front it could well be up there with the high end places in the immediate area and the food we had tonight was as good as; if not even better than the rather pretentious places nearby..!! Jolly good value too, we ate nearby recently and the bill for my wife and I was more expensive than the meal we had for 5 tonight..!!!! I'll be going back very soon. Well done.

We needed something to fill up on before a night out and we couldn't have been made more welcome. We got the last table in the corner of the bar and got our lovely fish and chips 15 minutes before the kitchen was due to open. The chips were especially gorgeous. Thank you so much

Four of us dropped in unannounced on Tuesday lunchtime. We were cold and wet so the fire in the corner was appreciated, as was the warm welcome we received.
We got our food order in early which was just as well because the bar filled rapidly, with many customers wanting food (a good sign).
Our food came after a little wait and it was excellent.
This pub has had a chequered history and previous incumbents have failed to offer a consistent service. The present team seem to be on the ball - long may it continue.

Nice little family-run (apparently) pub and bar, with a restaurant to the other side of the building. Lovely place for a bite of lunch on a cold, rainy day. Local beers (plus some big names) on tap. Excellent roasted-parsnip soup. Folks at the next table ordered sandwiches, which came with the most beautiful chips (fries) I've ever seen. Must go back. Nice people, fine service, very accommodating. Much better than a particular Greene King chain pub just up the road. (The White Swan is a bit plain on the outside, but don't let that put you off.)

Six of us sat down and had delightful, large starters, all were completely enjoyed, the main meals were very well cooked, very tasty and the plates totally cleared. The puddings were really great too, all served with a smiley waitress. We will certainly go there again. I believe very well priced too.

We were staying a the Quy Mill Great Western that was located a mile away from here. We decided that we wanted some good 'pub grub' for dinner and we definitely received this. The food was lovely! But in particular the pub has a warm, friendly atmosphere and provided fantastic service.

Dads 81st birthday meal with family. Assorted meals all really good. Pork Chop especially good. Atmosphere friendly the waitress was really good. It was her first time waitressing but she was excellent!

Convened here as central to family members and enjoyed a very good meal, the food was well cooked and served with a friendly smile. I enjoyed the venison steak which was cooked perfectly and accompanied by some chorizo. After a starter and main course most of us had to bypass the puddings and go straight to the coffees, although the puddings that were ordered looked tasty and were enthusiastically finished. Good ale, good food in nice surroundings no better way to enjoy a family Friday evening. Happily make a return visit.

Ordered the ribeye steak with peppercorn sauce, Unfortunately the steak was grisly and the peppercorn sauce was watery and tasted chemically. There were 5 steaks ordered for our party and only one of them was a good cut. The waitress was extremely helpful and friendly.

Went there as it was recommended as a sister pub of the The Brunswick in Cambridge, which is highly rated but currently closed. The ambience struck us as somewhat down market, but could have been forgiven if the food had been great. The waitress was new and very sweet. 100% for trying at giving good service., ....but the food! What a shocker. The grilled goats cheese looked as if it was microwaved. Edible, but certainly nothing to write home about. At this point we started to wonder. The menu was brief. Great we thought, they concentrate on doing a few things very well. Far from! My wife never returned a dish before in her life, but the watery tasteless vegetable soup served as pie was too much.

After the meal we found out that the White Swan and The Brunswick have parted their ways. Kind of explains it, but doesn't bring back a ruined evening.

The Michelin guide tells you when it is worth to go out of your way to visit a restaurant. This one deserves to go out of your way to avoid it.
Really enjoyed my meal and a pint. Great staff. The "pulled pork" pie was one of the best I have had. Highly recommended. Was serving up till 9pm in the week. I will be going back.

We called in for lunch on a wet bank holiday Monday and had a really good meal with good beer.
The pub was quite busy and there was a beer festival going on in the car park with a chap playing guitar and singing.
Our food came quickly and was really good. I had a burger and my wife had the bacon and brie ciabatta and both were very tasty. Our friends had a burger and an aubergine bake which were also good. The beer was excellent and the pub sells Becks blue non alcoholic lager which kept our driver (me) happy.
The service was welcoming and friendly.
A very nice pub which also had the air of being a really friendly local.

Stopped by for dinner after visiting Anglesey Abbey. The food was really good. I can recommend the beef and Guinness pie and the sea bass special. We decided to sit in the bar for a more informal atmosphere and the staff were very friendly and helpful.

Headed here on Sunday after a visit to Anglesey Abbey. Only the Sunday roast menu available so cant comment on other foods but the Sunday roast was AMAZING, I had the roast pork and my husband the roast beef. Both were absolutely delicious and very good portions. Staff were very friendly and attentive. Service very quick even though the restaurant was quite busy.
All very reasonably priced!
We'll definitely be going back when we are back in the area.

It was avery hot lunchtime, but I still went for the steak all and mushroom pie, as this is one of my yardsticks for judging a pub lunch. The White Swan passed with flying colours. The whole meal was delicious.

The bar staff are very friendly and helpful and wouldn't hesitate to recommend.

Lovely village setting where you can walk through fields of corn food is good as well with a good selection of real ale. Lamb with dipping breads starter for me, goats cheese followed by swordfish for my wife, very nice. Staff very helpful too.

On a Sunday evening not easy to find a local pub that serves food. However, the Sunday Evening Menu was quite extensive and the meal was freshly cooked, obviously from raw ingredients and was absolutely super served by lovely friendly staff. Not overly expensive and best of all, dog friendly in the bar. The best steak ever and good ales. Certainly a return visit soon.

I live next door to this pub and to be honest ive only dined here twice but food is good and the chef lucas is talented the landlord gerry is a nice guy but ii almost a recluesive figure but never mind you cant have every thing
Fantastic customer service, brilliant atmosphere & fantastic food; desserts were amazing, & very reasonably priced.

There is a big choice of food, our two dishes had fresh ingredients. I can recommend the local sausages and mash with 3 choices of mash, 3 gravies and 2 sausages - I had 2 venison and 1 pork; absolutely delicious. My wife had a large fish and chips. All the food being delivered to our and other tables smelled great. Good choice of Real Ales, with 3 hand pulls of different styles. Nice friendly staff in a lovely village pub. #1 choice for me in this area.

Traditional English village pub with a warm welcome from friendly staff. It is a free house and has four real ales on tap which are continually changing. They have a board above the bar displaying the ales that are in the cellar settling for the following days. The restaurant serves generous portions of "pub" food plus a few surprises which are prepared from good quality fresh ingredients to a very high standard. Definitely worth a visit.

We chose this country village pub pretty much at random and, with 4 adults, 2 teenagers and 3 kids descending for lunch we did book in advance. The menu had variety, suited all tastes, all our petty little requests (bit more of this, bit less of that, etc) were met with a cheerful 'no problem'. The pies were inventive, tasty and home made, the presentation of all our meals was excellent. But it is the no fuss but efficient service and the ability to be flexible which makes this pub stand out for me. We were well fed and well looked after - ticks all the boxes for me.

Decided at the last minute to have some lunch on the way back from shopping trip and had heard good things about this pub.

As soon as we walked in we were made to feel very welcome. Upon ordering nothing was too much trouble. We had a the fish finger ciabatta and goats cheese ciabatta.

Both very nice and will be going back to try the Sunday roasts which we have been recommended to us.

We'd just been to Anglesey Abbey and didn't fancy the NT food. Found this pub and had an excellent lunch with a very unusual but excellent crumble banana, pistachio and rhubarb (I think) accompanied with a crÃ¨me anglais flavoured with cardamom.

Recommended highly

We stopped here for Sunday lunch after a walk with the dog. I had the roast lamb and my wife had the nut roast, both were absolutely spot on, one of the best Sunday lunches I've had in a long time, the gravy on both meals was certainly the best gravy I've had anywhere.

Staff were very friendly and welcoming and even brought a bowl of water for our dog. Excellent service and a great selection of real ales.

Highly recommended!

Went here the night before my friends wedding. She highly recommended and it was lovely.
Really cute quiant pub in a lovely village setting.

Must have the pie it was probably the best pie I have ever had. My wife had the sausage and mash they have fancy gravy but she is pregnant so chef made a plain one. And you must have the ice cream it was very yummy. So I would say a must try if in the area thank for a good meal.

My friend and I had a lovely day at the Spa in Quy and we're starving when we left. We quickly checked online if the White Swan serves food on a Saturday night and went straight away. We stayed in the bar area and it was lovely. The atmosphere is like a real local pub and you feel very welcome. I had only been once before and I remember that I really enjoyed it then too. People are friendly, the menu is really nice and the food not only tastes very nice, it is also presented very nicely. I know that the owners also run the Brunswick in town and I'm looking forward to giving that a go. It's so nice to get a nice home cooked meal (I had a vegetarian pie and my friend had the fish pie followed by apple-strudel). I even asked for a take away dinner for my other half as the food was so nice. All in all I can just say, try for yourself, chances are you won't be disappointed!

The line-up of cask ales in this family-run free house usually includes the lovely citrusy JHB from Oakham Brewery alongside Adnams, Woodfordes and one or two more obscure names. They are all carefully looked after of course; they really care about beer at the White Swan.
The food is superb - top restaurant standard but much more affordable. Last night my friend and I both chose what turned out to be an amazing dish: medallions of wild boar fillet (served delightfully pink) with a caramelised onion and wild mushroom bread and butter pudding, green beans and a fabulously rich juniper gravy. Amazing! Those diners who chose from a wide selection of home-made pies were equally delighted and the cheeseboard was excellent too.
There was a great atmosphere in the pub which was populated by a good balance of dedicated locals and visitors. And, best of all, there was none of that ghastly canned music!
The toilets were spotless and we were even offered a lift home by a staff member at the end of the evening. It doesn't get much better!

We arrived at midday without booking and were seated in the bar area, right by a cosy log burner. The staff could not have been friendlier to us or our two young children with our meals arriving promptly. The portion sizes (2 adult, 2 kids) were very generous, and very good value. Just a shame that we had no room for some very tempting deserts.

Looks like just a standard pub from the outside, inside is a very warm welcome .
We went here as we were meeting a friend and this was in the middle of both destinations.

Arrived early 5.30pm, but they didn't serve food until 6pm, so we ordered drinks, sat down, a lovely friendly lady came over with the menus and a specials board and said that as soon as we had decided she would put the order through.

They food arrived was amazing, better than most restaurants that I have eaten in, the presentation was a work of art and it all tasted delicious.

I would recommend this pub and can not wait to go again.

Myself, my husband, my 3 young children, my mother and father in law and 2 of their friends came here to eat on the 1st Jan. I rang before we came to ask if my 5 month old puppy chihuahua was allowed in as well and they said yes, but just in the bar area which was fine.
We all sat down and ordered our food which we thought was a tad expensive (Â£11.50 for fish and chips) and had to wait a very long time for it to come out even though they were not busy. We asked for 3 child portions of fish and chips but only got 2, my young daughter received a adult size. We mentioned it as the lady brought it out and also when she took the plates away. Her reply was 'well it has all been eaten hasn't it?' What she should have said was 'sorry and of course you will not be charged for a adult size portion' but customer service didnt seem to be her strong point.
I took my puppy outside every 15 minutes to see if he needed the toilet but on the occassions I took him out he didnt. Then as I was in conversation my 8 year old son noticed he needed to go and went to take hom outside but the owner started to stroke our puppy by the door which stopped my son from taking him ot for a few seconds, by which this point our puppy had started to go to the toilet (number 2 unfortunately). BUT it was only 2 small bits and I very quickly took him outside to finish and my daughter picked the poo up from the mat by the door. As I was outside with the puppy while he finished, the lady owner snapped at me to get back inside to clear it up as it was upsetting all her customers (there was only about 4 people in there apart from us) and we had just spend alot of money with them!
When I went back in the man owner was cleaning it up and ranting and raving about the dog 'crapping everywhere' and how we hadnt apologised! I apologised myself 3 times to which his reply was a grunt.
I would like to point out that he was a puppy chihuahua so would hardly crap everywhere. Just a note, do not leg dogs in your pub unless you can expect and accept the odd accident. Your reaction was unecessary, rude and shocking. My children were upset by what happened and we just all sat there when we got home, gobsmacked. We had a lovely stay at the Missing Sock which is just up the road and was very sad to have ended it as it did at your pub.

Had lunch here last Saturday on the way to a birthday party in the area. Really impressed by the friendly service, which was very quick. We all ordered steak and agreed that it was one of the best steaks any of us had ever eaten. Moist, juicy, perfectly cooked and well priced. The chips were double-cooked I think and they were lovely. We had no room for dessert sadly! We'll definitely be back.

I visited the White Swan with friends on a Saturday evening, having pre-booked.

The staff are welcoming, the food is reasonably priced and the atmosphere is good. My only gripes are that, although our order for drinks was taken promptly, it took at least twenty minutes for them to be delivered to our table. I think this was because the waitress was doubling up on the bar. We also had to ask for the complimentary olive board, which is offered to parties who have pre-booked and then had to enjoy this as quickly as possible because our food was ready to be served up.

A nice place but pre-booking at the weekend is, I think, a must. Be prepared to adopt the continental style and have long waits between courses too!

The veggie nut roast was spot on and the lamb was a generous and well-cooked portion. Great vegetable s and yorkshire puds. Chocolate Brownie was to die for! Shame about the decor as it has a dated feel. A quick spruce and this would be a great place to come for any occasion.

Booked to hold a meeting here and was heartily welcomed. We arrived to have our meeting, and booked the meal at the start for later. Premises very clean and welcoming; staff exceptional and the food just marvellous. Well prepared and presented and tasted - just great! Food from 12 mid-day onwards. Thank you Martin. We are now looking forward to our next meeting - yes same place! A14 road just off at junction 35 and a few miles from Anglesey Abbey. Combine the two for a great day out.

Unpretentious pub with friendly landlady and staff. God range of unteresting beers including wherry, jhb. Food was more interesting than ecpected and the potato wedges were a meal on their own and very irresistable. Yum! Thank you.
Nice pub full of nice people. It is good that it stays open late (about 2am) for the people who want to carry on the night but not to a club.

We came in on the back of previous good reviews. Booked online for a tuesday and was surprised to find the place full (turns out there was a quiz but the restaurant was fairly full too). Opted for bar menu and had a steak pie and fish and chips, both were just awesome. Although we waited we were given free olives as we'd booked which was a nice touch

It's always reassuring to see a menu with only a handful of choice dishes. The smoked fish tureen was excellent, as I'm told was the rack of lamb, fish and chips and lamb pie. My steak was a bit chewy, but given that everyone else loved their food, including the kids, we will certainly be coming back soon.

Called in on a Monday night at 8.00pm. Restaurant had just two diners but the chef kindly agreed to preapre meals for three of us. Staff were attentive and freindly, food was reasonably priced and tasty and there was a good selection of beer. Sadly , as with so many pubs, it was quiet on this night, but if you are looking for a pub that looks the part and seems like it could get lively at the weekends, then give it a go.
The White Swan is a very friendly local pub with a welcoming landlord and staff. There menu is better than the average pub and the food is affordable. A popular bike tour stop.

Another excellent and enormous roast at Quy. We come back here for the sharing platter whenever we go out for Sunday lunch for the huge portions on lamb, beef and pork, plus the giant Yorkshire pudding. Highly recommended. Very high quality house red too this week. I'd also recommend the boozy Irish coffee afterwards. Big thumbs up to The White Swan again.

Decided to have Sunday lunch on our way back from Anglesey abbey. Good choice, the beef and lamb were both great in taste and value the cheesecake was a delight. Staff were polite and attentive.
Decor a little tired but looks to be work in progress!

Will be visiting again but next time with the grandchildren so be warned!!!

Found the pub on tastecard and looked worth a trip out to SCQ.
I shouldnt have bothered .
Despite taking my booking in the restaurant when i arrived i was offered bar menu only as they had a beer festival on in the garden.
When i complained they produced another menu which was still poor and nothing like they advertise on their website.
It was hugely irritating and a waste of my time as we left without eating.
One member of staff was very sweet and clearly embarassed by the whole affair, whereas the lady who held herself out to be the owner seemed a bit nonplussed by it all and offered nothing other than a shrug and a cursory sorry about that.
I wont be going back.

Staying in the area we saw the reviews of the restaurant and decided to give it a try. We were not disappointed. We opted for starters, I had the goats cheese salad and my husband had the salmon with a dill and caper sauce. Both were tasty and well presented.
For main course I decided on the sausages and chose the grain mash with the sherry and onion sauce. I was very glad I did as it was delicious. I had a side dish of season vegetables and onion rings. My husband chose the home made burger served with hand cup chips and home made salsa. He was impressed.
I didn't have room for a dessert but my husband had spotted the bread and butter pudding on the menu and was determined to sample it at all costs. He said that it was the best he had tasted.
The service was prompt and both the waitress and the landlord were chatty and friendly. I would definitely recommend anyone in the area to give it a try, you won't be disappointed!

Restaurant -Haddock was extremely good and tasted very fresh, chips were excellent - the peas served in a jug found a bit odd and unnecessary? My husband had the pork loin/belly - loin was bland, belly was delicious - sauce OK but only a tablesponful served in a little bottle. Smoked mash? (not quite sure what to expect!) he found a bit off putting and not very nice - mustard or apple would have been nicer with the pork.When we arrived we had to wait a few minutes while 3 people behind the counter were trying to sort out which tables were going where when there was only 3 other people in the restaurant. However the waitress brought our menus straight away but when reading out the specials forgot to mentioned the sea bass. Ordered some wine which she brought but sat there for 10 minutes and had to ask for the wine glasses as she had forgotten. Wine was very good and reasonably priced.. The ambience of the restaurant could possibly be improved -on the table were small tumblers for water and no wine glasses which gave the impression more of a cafe than a restaurant as did the chairs. The bar had a lovely atmosphere. We will return sometime in the future I'm sure!

We meet friends here for Sunday lunch just before christmas and it was lovely - I would say there is not much choice on the meat menu for the lunch - I like chicken and turkey but they only had Beef or Pork on the menu. I had the pork and must say even though im not a fan of pork it was very nice. Staff were friendly and it was very resonably priced !
Lovely pub but Â£4.90 for a bottle of magners!!! Shame, won't go back! Much cheaper pubs nearby which are just as nice.

We came in on the back of previous good reviews. Booked online for a tuesday and was surprised to find the place full (turns out there was a quiz but the restaurant was fairly full too). Opted for bar menu and had a steak pie and fish and chips, both were just awesome. Although we waited we were given free olives as we'd booked which was a nice touch

I have popped in before a couple of times but I finally decided to begin writing reviews!

This is one of my favourite pub/ restaurants in Cambridge. The food is excellent, I've never been disappointed. It always seems to be busy but I always get my food relatively quickly. Staff are always really friendly, though they all seem to know me by now!

I couldn't recommend this place enough. Can't wait for my next visit!

Four of us stopped at the White Swan for light lunch, three ciabatta with hot fillings and a jacket potato. We were still waiting for these over an hour later, despite the pub being almost empty. When the food eventually arrived, the potato had to be sent back because the flesh was brown which should have been seen when the potato was cut open in the kitchen. An alternative was chosen of a chicken caesar salad which arrived after the ciabattas had been eaten. This was inedible, the chicken was still raw in the middle - as the chicken had been silced, this should have been seen in the kitchen, the salad comprised of three outer leaves of lettuce, one of which was yellow.

The ciabatas were adequate but one was described in the menu as containing toasted peppers with hummus but was actually peppers and brie. It was fortunate that the person who chose this was not dairy intolerant.

The only credit I can give to the White Swan is the way that the manager dealt with our complaints but this is offset by the thought that food of such poor quality should never have been allowed to leave the kitchen.
Reasonable food but over priced.Large party booked but tables split.Should have been made aware of this when booked.

Dined here for Easter Sunday lunch with family on strength of reviews and reputation, wish we had gone elsewhere. Food ok, nothing more than average. Meat was either overcooked i.e. pork and beef was very rare (we were not advised of this), vegetables were warm and gravy a little cold. Yorkshire puddings had been cooked to the point of death in places but were stodgy in others. Plates were also cold which didnt help. Starters of soup and smoked salmon were ok but portions were small and soup lacked flavour. Beer according to male members of our party was good. We did remark that food was cold on 2 occasions and were advised that the "kitchen would be told" and chef "cuts the meat at half hourly intervals", not quite sure what they meant by that and couldnt be bothered to ask them to explain. To be honest it was below average but cant score anything other than poor and at least wine and beer were nice. Not cheap for a Sunday lunch and expected a lot more!

Arrived just before 7 pm and restaurant was empty. I never like to go into an empty restaurant but i needn't have worried. It wasn't long before several other diners arrived and there was a great atmosphere. The waitress was great, attentive without being intrusive. The food surpassed my expectations, which were already high based on reviews on here. I had sirloin with a mushroom sauce and my partner had crunch topped rack of lamb. Both were excellent. For dessert we both had bread and butter pudding. An old favourite. My cousin was a chef and his b&b pudding is hard to beat but the chef at the white swan took this old favourite to new heights.

Good choice of wines and great coffee completed an excellent dining experience. Highly recommended.

I have been to this quaint village pub for Sunday lunch 3 times now, and I really can't fault it. Good value, very tasty food, and pleasant service. It does get busy so booking is reccomended.
Unfortunately I haven't tried anything from their regular menu, but hope to soon, if it's anything like their Sunday lunches!
As I have always drove to this pub, it is nice to see that they have a good selection of non alcholic beers (as well as a good stocked bar for those not driving!)
For a good Sunday lunch, deffinitely give it a go!

First dinner here and we were not disappointed. The menu was a delightful combination of traditional favourites and other more experimental flavours. The fish and the steak were exceptional, as were the sausages and home made burgers .Enjoyed the wine too. Only criticism was the room temperature, it was one of the coldest weeks of the year however. But will certainly be adding this local gastro pub to my list of favourites.

The White Swan is a village pub close to Anglesey Abbey(NT). The beer from Adnams and Woodfordes, red and white wines by the glass were good. I was pleased to see two Englsh whiskies from the St. George's Distillery in South Norfolk were stocked, alongside Scottish Malts.The lunchtime food from the Seasonal Bar Menu and Lite Bite Menu were disappointing. We had a long wait of about 40 minutes for our order to arrive. A small helping of pork belly was Â£13.50! A small burger and chips cost Â£8.95, and the steak ciabatta appeared to contain a thin slice of dry roast beef, just warmed up. A selection of three different sausages with mash and gravy was OK. A let down by the kitchen both in timing and quality. A slimmer menu with less choice but better food would be a good idea. The staff were very friendly and helpful, and we had apologies for our long wait. Our second round of drinks were not charged for - a decent gesture!

We had had a lovely morning strolling in uncharacteristically bright winter sunshine in Anglesey Abbey and chanced upon this pub as we were driving away home.
We sat in the front bar, unaware of the restaurant at the rear, but ordered from a specials as well as a permanent menu. We had to wait nearly 40 minutes for our order and the staff seemed quite overwhelmed, but very friendly and helpful all the same. I ordered a vegetarian mille feuille aubergine and pepper with goats cheese arrangement, others ordered pork, game pie and caesar salad. Unconventional-looking but all tasty. Bread and butter pudding was served in a very bright yellow sauce which was creamy and tasty, but no idea what made it so yellow! Yes, we were glad to sit and chat together, but would have had to leave if we were clock-watching. Take your time and relax as the wait is well rewarded.

We went there on a Sunday lunchtime after a lovely walk. The only choice on the menu for nonvegetarians was a Sunday roast. Three of us were tempted by the beef as it was described as pink and medium rare. In fact it was far from pink although edible if you like your beef well done. The yorkshire pudding however was not just well done but cremated. If I had burnt yorkshire puddings at home like this they would have gone in the bin and not on the plate! The roast potatoes were pale and soggy and could have done with the cooking that the meat and yorkshire pudding had been exposed to. The roast vegetables were also uninspiring. On a positive note the side vegetables were lovely and my vegetarian daughter had a lovely meal of stuffed mushroom. The chocolate brownie we had for pudding was very acceptable and the service was effiecient and friendly. Maybe Sunday is a bad day to eat at the White Swan unless you enjoy a roast lunch.

We were a party of 9 and only booked on the day, so were very pleased that the restaurant was able to accommodate us (especially as the reviews on Trip Advisor were so good).

We were told that another large group were arriving just before us, so were pleased to be seated straight away and had our orders taken as soon as we were ready. The staff were very friendly and helpful. We were given a restaurant menu and a bar menu and there were some specials on the black board.

Across the group we ordered a mixture of starters and main courses. The starters got a mixed reception. The root vegetable soup (of the day) was very peppery (possibly just over seasoned) and the pork rillettes were basically pork pate (a little disappointing given the lavish description in the menu). However a sausage and mash starter (not on the menu but kindly made specially) was really good. My wife had the caesar salad and was surprised by the poached and deep fried egg (although this is what is says in the menu), but it was very fresh.

The main courses were a mix across fish and chips, burgers, game pie and the vegetarian option. The fish was good and there were no complaints from the burger eaters. The game pie was ok, but a little surprised no vegetables were supplied as well (there were some carrots in the pie). Some gravy on the side with the pie would also have been appreciated.

Desserts were good, with a selection of lemon sorbet and the chef's sharing chocolate assiette. The espresso was very bitter

The real ale and wine we had with the meal was OK as well, but nothing to write home about to be honest

So, nice venue, friendly staff, and some nice food offset by other average to poor dishes. I hope to visit again sometime soon and will try some of the other dishes. I wish the team at the White Swan well and hope they will take the comments in this review in the spirit they are meant.
had two visits to the Swan now and both times have been impressed with the standard of food served,would recommend Tony

Booked table for husband,myself,daughterand teenage grandson at 12.30today. As we entered the restaurant the freezing cold air hit you. After half hour a waitress lit the fire and the candles and put the lights on the tree. It was as if we had not been there. Another elderly diner sat with coat and scarf on. Ordered soup as to get warm. Soup so hot it was almost boiling. My burnt mouth still hurts. The main came and my beef was stone cold and the teaspoon of gravy under it. Also the veg, only warm item was roast potatoes. Other three meals luke warm. Asked for more gravy in the hope it would warm it up and the smallest gravy boat I've ever seen arrived. Only one for four meals. Decided we had had enough and did not order sweet, but I asked for a pot of tea and my daughter a coffee. My tea arrived but no milk and the piece of fudge missing from my daughters. My husband had to go and ask for the milk. When I went to pay I started to tell them about the meal but the waitress just laughed and said 'oh dear - the room too cold and the soup too hot. ' This was accompained by a sarcastic laugh which I and my family did not find funny. She also said that yes the room was cold (no apology) when we arrived but they didnt know how long it would take to heat up. It was now 2.30pm and the room was hot. It was such a shame as we had eaten here before and it was good but I will never set foot in the place again.

Although the centre of Cambridge might have good restaurants I was very hard pressed to find anything worth a visit on the outskirts, especially as it was Sunday night. So, I was pleased to find that the White Swan, close to the A14 and only a few minutes away from Cambridge, does do food - very good food - on Sunday nights. It is a bar menu, but the chef had also come up with some very tempting specials. I opted for home made soup and then home made pie. Both were quality dishes, very freshly produced and tasty and were presented attractively and piping hot - though I do prefer my pie on the plate rather than in an individual dish. Although I was on my own in the restaurant the staff were very friendly and considerate.
What impressed me equally, was the jolly, friendly chap on the phone when I made my booking.
I very much look forward to another visit.

We went for Sunday lunch there and as 2 of our group were vegetarians we all tried the vegetarian Sunday roast and it was delicious, the service was excellent, even bring us an extra helping of gravy, the Yorkshire pudding were huge and tasty. It was quite filling but there was still room to try their bread and butter pudding with a twist...their custard had cardamoms in it to give it a hint of something more exotic and the bread and butter pudding also had apricots....delicious! we were happily stuffed by the end of the meal and needed a long walk across Quy fen to walk it off. We will be back!

I stayed at the Best Western in Stow Quy in early October for work. Although a very nice atmosphere it lacked a personal feel and you just felt like a room number, so began my search for a decent evening meal and drink. I ended up spending 4 nights at the White Swan (it would have been 5 but a friend dragging me into Cambridge.

Don't get me wrong, I love sampling different restaurants and am not a creature of habit but after the first night at the Swan I was compelled to try as much of the menu as I possibly could! The food here is very good indeed and I like to think my standards are high! The Pork belly was devine as was the fish and chips and sausage and mash where you could choose the sausage, mash and sauce combination to suit your tastebuds. The highlight for me was Steak night where you get a free starter or dessert if you order one if the gorgeous steaks on offer.

They also have very good knowledge of their wine and Martin picked a perfect red to accompany my steak but what also makes a meal here pretty damn good is the price. For the standard of food and drink it's very reasonable, gastro pub food and drink at normal pub prices (maybe I am too used to London bills)

To top this all off is the fantastically warm welcome and feel from this family run establishment. It didn't take long for me to feel like I had been going there for years. I got a taxi service back to my hotel from the very knowledgeable and very welcoming Gerry who was one of the nicest pub landlords I have ever known and I wish them all the best with their business as I am sure a lot of sweat, blood and tears go behind trying to make their pub a success.

All I would say is give this place a go! I would love to have this pub as my local and hope to maybe visit again.
Excellent steak, excellent sauce, excellent service, excellent beer Happy people, highly recommended

We are new to this region only here for a few days, had a wonderful meal great service and really good value, very homely atmosphere with top class food would def recommend and if in area again no hesitation in coming back well done.

Second visit to the White Swan since it last changed hands and frankly this is exactly the kind of place I want to go to. 4 real ales, decent bar and restaurant menu, happy people and a chef in the kitchen that can actually cook (makes a refreshing change). The blend one wants to see, a real pleasant place to go. I wish the staff and owners every success. Shame we live 30 miles away!

I have now eaten twice at the White Swan. I like the place very much. The first time, I had the best steak and kidney pie that I have ever eaten. Now, yesterday I tried the fish and chips. Really very good. Finally I asked for an Iced Latte which was not on the menu. After explaining what I wanted they came up with exactly what I was after. Very refreshing indeed. I suggested they add it to their menu.
I will definitely eat there again, the next time that I am visiting Cambridge and the vicinity.

My husband and I booked table here to celebrate my birthday as it looked like it might have been a great plae to eat. However, we were very disappointed. To start with we were late sitting down because the waiter "was stressed out" as restaurant was busy (it's tiny though!). The starters were fine with lots of flavour and not bad value for money however out main courses arrived and they weren't much bigger than a starter. We both ordered dishes that came with seasonal vegetables, these seasonal vegetables consisted of 3 carrots each. Whilst the food was all very pleasant it was very overpriced. The service was very poor, no one came to see if our meals were okay and when we asked for more drinks and some water we felt as if we were wrong for asking for more drinks and if we were being an inconveniene. We didn't bother with dessert just asked for the bill and left. Â£50 well and truly wasted and left still hungry!

Have eaten here twice over the last month and both times have been excellent.

First time was a quiet romantic meal and we both enjoyed the friendly service and good quality food - the seabass in particular was perfect.

Second time was for a Birthday and we took the kids. Lots of options on the menu for fussy eaters. They really worked hard to accommodate some of the off menu kids requests (cheesy mash!).

It's great to have found somewhere local that serves fresh, good quality food with a good choice of beers.

Recommended without hesitation.

We had a family reunion there on Saturday and had a fabulous meal. The service was excellent - nice friendly staff and could not fault the food or service. Superb presentation of food and generous portions - top quality. They do not yet have good disabled facilities but am sure this will come as they are trying so hard to make it a pub for everyone.
Well worth a visit and the best pub in the area.
The M family
